sentences: Terri Lynn Clark (née Sauson; August 5, 1968) is a Canadian country music singer who has had success in both Canada and the United States.
Signed to Mercury Records in 1995, she released her self-titled debut that year.
Both it and its two follow-ups, 1996's Just the Same and 1998's How I Feel, were certified platinum in both countries, and produced several Top Ten country hits.
Both it and its two follow-ups, 1996's Just the Same and 1998's How I Feel, were certified platinum in both countries, and produced several Top Ten country hits.
Her fourth album, 2000's Fearless, though certified gold in Canada, was not as successful in the U.S., producing no Top 10 hits.
Pain to Kill from 2003 restored her chart momentum in the U.S. with "I Just Wanna Be Mad" and "I Wanna Do It All", while a 2004 greatest hits album produced the Number One "Girls Lie Too".
A non-album single, "The World Needs a Drink", and the 2005 album Life Goes On were her last releases for Mercury before she signed to BNA Records in 2007.
A non-album single, "The World Needs a Drink", and the 2005 album Life Goes On were her last releases for Mercury before she signed to BNA Records in 2007.
Clark was born Terri Lynn Sauson on August 5, 1968, in Montreal, Quebec, Canada.

sentences: After graduating from Crescent Heights High School in 1987, she moved to Nashville where she got her start playing at Tootsie's Orchid Lounge, a honky-tonk bar across the alley from Nashville's iconic Ryman Auditorium.

== Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: After a management change in December 2001, Clark began work on her fifth studio album, Pain to Kill.
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: The album was issued in January 2003, followed after the release of the album's first single, "I Just Wanna Be Mad".
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: When released as a single the song became Clark's highest-charting single in the United States since 1998's "You're Easy on the Eyes" and is to date Clark's highest appearance on the U.S. Billboard Hot 100, peaking at No. 27.
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: In early 2004, Clark was approached by Playboy magazine to pose—clothed—for the cover of the magazine's upcoming May issue.
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: "On May 15, 2004, during a performance of the Grand Ole Opry, Clark was surprised by Steve Wariner and her mother Linda with an invitation to join the Grand Ole Opry.
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: Clark was officially inducted on June 12, 2004, and is currently the only female Canadian member of the Grand Ole Opry.
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: Shortly after her induction, Clark's first greatest hits album, Greatest Hits 1994–2004, was issued.
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: The album's only single, "Girls Lie Too", became Clark's first number one in the United States since 1998's "You're Easy on the Eyes".
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: While the song did not reach number one in Canada, it was the named number one country song of 2004 in Canada by Radio & Records.
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===

sentences: A non-album single, "The World Needs a Drink" (which was co-written by a then-unknown Eric Church), was released in late 2004, but was not included on any of Clark's studio albums.
section: == Biography == | === 2002–2004: Pain to Kill and Greatest Hits 1994-2004 ===
== Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: In 2005, Clark's sixth studio album, Life Goes On, was issued in November.
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: None of the album's other singles charted in the United States and Clark parted ways with Mercury Records in March 2006.
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: In June 2006, Clark signed with BNA Records, a division of Sony BMG label group, now known as Sony Music Entertainment.
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: Clark's first single for the label, "Dirty Girl", was issued in early 2007.
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: My Next Life was delayed several times and remained unreleased leaving Clark to part ways with BNA in November 2008, so she could concentrate more on her career in Canada and possibly launch her own record label.
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: Clark released a live album, Terri Clark Live: Road Rage, via Clark's own BareTrack Records label in July 2009 through digital retailers.
section: == Biography == | === 2005–2010: Life Goes On and The Long Way Home ===

sentences: Clark's seventh studio album, The Long Way Home, was released shortly after to all retailers in Canada and digital retailers in the United States on September 1, 2009, via BareTrack/Capitol Nashville/EMI Canada.

sentences: The album was released to non-digital retailers in the United States on October 20, 2009.

sentences: Clark, who came in second place behind fellow Canadian country singer Shania Twain in a poll in the previous year, turned down the offer saying "I think of all the young girls who come to my shows, I think of those faces, I think of my mother, and I worry about the signal [sex] sends to them[…] If I’m sexy enough for Playboy to want me with my clothes on, then I hope the message can be that sexy is about what’s between your ears, in your heart and your smile.
